historicalContext.significance: Documents one of the most destructive riots in American history, sparked by public outrage over a lenient manslaughter verdict in a clear murder case. The riots resulted in 56 deaths, over 300 wounded, and the complete destruction of the courthouse by fire.

description: Historic 1884 wood engraving from Frank Leslie's Illustrated Newspaper depicting the Cincinnati Courthouse Riots of March 28-30, 1884. Shows the attack on the Hamilton County Courthouse and jail complex located on Court Street and Sycamore Street in downtown Cincinnati. The riots were triggered by public outrage over the lenient sentencing of William Berner, who received only a manslaughter conviction despite confessing to the brutal murder of his employer. The three-day riot involved approximately 10,000 citizens, resulted in 56 deaths and over 300 wounded, and culminated in the complete destruction of the courthouse by fire. This engraving captures a pivotal moment in Cincinnati's history that exposed municipal corruption and ultimately led to significant judicial and political reforms.
